item.title: Who Are UNIFIL Peacekeepers at Lebanon-Israel Border?
item.description: Established to maintain peace in southern Lebanon, the UNIFIL forces have been increasingly caught in the middle of the Israeli-Hezbollah war.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Italian member of the U.N. peacekeepers in Lebanon in July.

item.title: Israel Fired on Peacekeepers in Lebanon, U.N. Says
item.description: Israel was behind the attack, Lebanon said, and it came on the same day that the U.N. said Israeli forces had fired on its peacekeepers, an episode that drew international condemnation.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Liam Stack, Aric Toler and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Carrying a body amid destroyed buildings in central Beirut that Lebanon said had been hit by an Israeli airstrike on Thursday night.

item.title: Ukraine’s Parliament Approves Biggest Tax Increase of War to Support the Army
item.description: The authorities are resorting to a politically unpopular move as they scramble to raise funds for the grueling military effort against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firing from a position near Selydove, eastern Ukraine, this month. The tax rise is likely to hit hard in the country, where people have already seen their economic well-being plummet because of the war.

item.title: In One Photo: Lebanon’s Dahiya Area After Strikes
item.description: Once lively and densely packed, the area on the edges of Beirut that was hit by an Israeli strike is now vacant.
item.dc:creator: David Guttenfelder
item.media:description: In One Image Rubble, and Defiance By David Guttenfelder

item.title: Meeting of Western Leaders on Ukraine Is Postponed in Setback for Kyiv
item.description: A top-level gathering in Germany intended to show support for Ukraine was put off after President Biden canceled his trip to deal with Hurricane Milton.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Constant Méheut and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden disembarking from Marine One on Tuesday after arriving at the White House.

item.title: Black Girls Hike Founder Seeks to Make U.K. Hiking More Inclusive
item.description: Motivated by the racial disparity she saw on trails, Rhiane Fatinikun founded Black Girls Hike to make Britain’s countryside more inclusive.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rhiane Fatinikun, the founder of Black Girls Hike, on Ingleborough, a peak in the Yorkshire Dales National Park in England, after climbing it with a group of hikers this year.

item.title: Faced With Regional Setbacks, India Flexes Its New Economic Muscle
item.description: Tapping into a fast-growing economy, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been offering financial help to India’s neighbors as he tries to counter China’s influence.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, right, with President Mohamed Muizzu of the Maldives in New Delhi on Monday. Mr. Muizzu called India, which offered more than $750 million in aid, “a key partner.”

item.title: Man Charged for South Africa Mass Shooting that Killed 18 People
item.description: The killings of 18 members of one family assembled for a gathering last month are among an increasing number of mass shootings in South Africa.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A photo supplied by the South Africa Police Services showing where 18 people were slain last month at a family gathering near the rural town of Lusikisiki, South Africa.

item.title: Biden and Netanyahu Speak as Israel Weighs Retaliation Against Iran
item.description: The conversation carried the weight of the worst relationship between the United States and Israel in years.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at the White House in July. Their call on Wednesday came at a moment when U.S. national security officials believe the Middle East is on a knife’s edge.

item.title: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary Gets a Hostile Serenade in Strasbourg
item.description: Some progressive members sang “Bella Ciao,” a song associated with antifascism, to show opposition to Prime Minister Viktor Orban, who’s been accused of authoritarianism at home.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary spoke Wednesday at the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France.

item.title: Who Will Be U.K. Conservative Leader? The Contest Narrows to an Unexpected Choice.
item.description: After an epic election defeat in July, opposition lawmakers have presented their party’s dues-paying members with an unexpected choice of two candidates from the right.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Robert Jenrick, one of the two finalists for the Conservative Party leadership in Britain, has appealed to the right by promising to slash annual immigration numbers.

item.title: A Gaza Family Separated by a Few Miles, and the War
item.description: Najia and Hammam Malaka have been stuck at opposite ends of the Gaza Strip, with their young children, for most of the yearlong conflict. The emotional toll has been devastating.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Bilal Shbair
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising after an airstrike in Gaza City last year. Hammam Malaka worried every time there were reports of airstrikes near where his wife and three youngest children were staying.

item.title: Prestigious U.S.-Ireland Mitchell Scholarship Paused Amid Funding Woes
item.description: More than 300 American students have benefited from the George J. Mitchell program, founded after the Good Friday Agreement, but it has been halted indefinitely.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trinity College Dublin, where some of this year’s George J. Mitchell scholarship students are studying.

item.title: ‘Relentless’ Israeli Attacks on Gaza Medical Workers Are War Crime, U.N. Panel Says
item.description: The report, which does not have the force of law, found that the Israeli military has engaged in deliberate assaults on hospitals and other health care providers.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A medical worker near a destroyed hospital in Gaza City in September.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Florida Hurricane Kills at Least 7
item.description: Plus, Han Kang receives the Nobel Prize in Literature.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of an apartment complex in Clearwater, Fla., were rescued from floodwaters.

item.title: Airstrikes in Beirut Kill at Least 22 and Injure Over 100, Lebanon Says
item.description: The attack, for which Lebanese officials blamed Israel, appeared to be the deadliest in the Lebanese capital in more than a year of fighting between the Israeli military and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Ephrat Livni and Aric Toler
item.media:description: Several buildings in central Beirut were hit by airstrikes on Thursday.

item.title: The Forecast: 832 Degrees in Brazil? Weather App Glitch Sends Extreme Weather to New Heights
item.description: No, it will not actually reach 832 degrees in Brazil’s capital this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Sara Ruberg
item.media:description: The BBC apologized on Thursday for its inaccurate weather predictions that showed wild winds and insanely high temperatures for cities around the world.

item.title: Israel’s Security Cabinet Met to Discuss Response to Iran Attack
item.description: The cabinet was expected to authorize initiating a retaliatory attack, officials said. They didn’t make their decision public.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier inspects the remains of an Iranian ballistic missile in southern Israel on Wednesday.

item.title: While N.B.A. Plays in Abu Dhabi, Critics Cry Foul
item.description: The league has held preseason games in the United Arab Emirates for three years. It says its impact has been positive, but others say it’s helping a repressive regime.
item.dc:creator: Tania Ganguli and Hilary Swift
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Jaden Springer with the ball in the second game, played at Etihad Arena on Sunday.

item.title: Nima Rinji Sherpa Becomes Youngest Climber to Summit 14 Highest Mountains
item.description: Nima Rinji Sherpa’s achievement highlights the role of Sherpas in an activity where they shoulder much of the risk but receive little glory.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: 14 Peaks Expedition, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The mountaineer Nima Rinji Sherpa at Annapurna Base Camp in Nepal in March.

item.title: Latest WWF Wildlife Survey Points to ‘Alarming’ Declines
item.description: The results from an important ongoing assessment look grim. But the survey is often misunderstood.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the Colombian Amazon. The Living Planet Index found a reduction of 73 percent in the average size of monitored wildlife populations worldwide from 1970 to 2020.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Florida Braces for Hurricane Milton
item.description: Plus, literature’s greatest prize.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cape Coral, Fla., yesterday.

item.title: Nearly a Million in Lebanon Flee Israel-Hezbollah Conflict, U.N. Says
item.description: A week into the ground war between Israel and Hezbollah, shelters in Lebanon are filling up beyond capacity, humanitarian officials warned.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Aryn Baker, Ben Hubbard and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Emergency personnel at work after a fire at a residential building caused by a rocket fired from Lebanon, in Kiryat Shmona, northern Israel, on Wednesday.

item.title: Democracy Struggles in an Era of Mistrust and Upheaval
item.description: The Athens Democracy Forum last week explored the world’s schisms in the face of threats from technology and shifts in the world order.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Achilles Tsaltas, the president of the Democracy & Culture Foundation, which organizes the Athens Democracy Forum, at the 2024 event last week.

item.title: Conditions in Gaza Worsen Amid Israeli Strikes
item.description: UNICEF said women and children were killed in an airstrike while waiting for malnutrition treatment.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Palestinians inspecting a destroyed school after an airstrike on Thursday in Deir al Balah, in central Gaza.

item.title: Biden and Netanyahu Speak for First Time Since August
item.description: Ties between the U.S. and Israeli leaders have been strained over Israel’s conduct in Gaza. The Israeli defense minister delayed a much-anticipated trip to the U.S. at Mr. Netanyahu’s request.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Defense Minister Yoav Gallant of Israel, center, in Washington in March.

item.title: A Filmmaker Focuses on Climate and Democracy
item.description: In his next documentary, Michael P. Nash takes on A.I. and how it might be used to address environmental issues.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: Turkish Airlines Pilot Dies, Forcing Emergency Landing
item.description: The airline said the pilot had lost consciousness during the flight, which was headed to Istanbul from Seattle.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Clark Hodgin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Turkish Airlines plane at Kennedy International Airport in New York City.

item.title: Lily Ebert, Holocaust Survivor, Author and TikTok Star, Dies at 100
item.description: She survived Auschwitz, wrote a best-selling memoir, “Lily’s Promise,” and spoke to a following of 2 million fans on TikTok.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner

item.title: Flooding Ravages Thai District Known for Elephant Parks
item.description: Two people have died following the intense rains that inundated the city of Chiang Mai and surrounding areas that are popular with tourists.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Elephant Nature Park, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Iranian Official Heads to Saudi Arabia as Israel Postpones U.S. Meeting
item.description: The Biden administration is dealing with complex dynamics in the Middle East as it tries to keep conflicts involving Israel from escalating further.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Destruction in Hod Hasharon, Israel, last week after an Iranian missile attack.

item.title: Trump Family Business Eyes Hotel Deals in Israel
item.description: The Trump Organization was in talks about Israeli hotels before the Hamas attack last year. It says it wants to resume them in the future, raising questions about the mingling of politics and money in the event of a second Trump term.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin, Steve Eder and Ben Protess
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump Organization discussed a branding deal involving the Haleom Hotel, under construction in Jerusalem.

item.title: Mozambique’s 2024 National Elections: What to Know
item.description: Four candidates are vying for the presidency in a country that has faced a yearslong ISIS-backed insurgency. The election is also a test of the sway of former independence movements.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Tavares Cebola
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A wall plastered with election campaign posters for Daniel Francisco Chapo, the candidate for the governing party, Frelimo, in Maputo, Mozambique, on Tuesday.

item.title: As I Am: L.G.B.T.Q. in Japan
item.description: ‘We don’t want to send the message to the younger generation that we’re people who have to hide ourselves.’
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee, Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Satoko Nagamura, right, with her partner, Mamiko Moda, and their son in Tokyo.

item.title: In This Office, the Fading Dream of a Unified Korea Lives On
item.description: On paper, five South Korean officials are the governors of North Korean provinces. Their goal is reunification, but fewer and fewer Koreans share it.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: A meeting Tuesday of the “governors” appointed by South Korea to run provinces in North Korea. They have no real power in the North; the appointments are a way for the South to claim sovereignty there.

item.title: How Harrods of London Is Dealing With a Sexual Abuse Scandal
item.description: The 175-year-old department store is trying to make amends for alleged abuse by its former owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, even while shoppers seem undeterred.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: People walking past the Harrods department store in London in 2022. Mohamed Al Fayed, who owned the store from 1985 until 2010, allegedly used it as a hunting ground for young women whom he would select from the storeroom floor and then elevate to work in his personal office.

item.title: Climate Change Increased Rain and Wind Speeds of Helene
item.description: In cooler times, a similarly rare storm over the Southeast would have delivered less rain and weaker winds, a team of scientists concluded in an analysis.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Mike Belleme for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage in Swannona, N.C., on Sept. 28.

item.title: Ruth Glacier in Alaska Hides America’s Deepest Gorge
item.description: A famed explorer was sure the ice hid something profound. Ninety years later, scientists have put forth the strongest evidence yet that he was right.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Jason Gulley
item.media:description: Chloe Steiner, a mountain guide, descended into a cave inside Ruth Glacier.

item.title: Israel Sends More Soldiers Into Lebanon as Strikes Hit Beirut and Damascus
item.description: In an attack of its own, Hezbollah fired 180 “projectiles” into Israel, according to the Israeli military, which said most were intercepted.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Natan Odenheimer, Ronen Bergman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from multiple Israeli airstrikes targeting the southern suburbs of Beirut on Tuesday.

item.title: Brazil Unblocks X After Musk Backs Down
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court said Tuesday that Elon Musk’s social network could return in the country after a monthlong ban because the company had complied with the court’s orders.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters criticizing the Brazilian Supreme Court’s decision to ban X during a demonstration in São Paulo last month.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: An Israeli Airstrike in Syria
item.description: Plus, revisiting Oppenheimer’s Communist ties.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: A residential building on the western outskirts of Damascus, Syria, yesterday.

item.title: Yoav Gallant, Israel’s Defense Minister, Postpones Trip to DC, US Says
item.description: Yoav Gallant and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III were expected to discuss Israel’s response to the Iranian missile assault on Israel last week.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Yoav Gallant, the Israeli defense minister, in Tel Aviv, last year.

item.title: Biden Excoriated Netanyahu on Israel’s Conduct in the War, Woodward Book Says
item.description: The book, “War,” lays bare just how frustrated the president has become with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu since the war in Gaza began.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with President Biden at the White House in July.

item.title: Toronto Woman Is Accused of Murdering 3 in Serial Killings
item.description: Victims who were found in a span of three days in Canada last week included two men whom the police said the suspect had attacked at random.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Steve Russell/Toronto Star via Getty Images
item.media:description: The police outside of the Toronto home of Sabrina Kauldhar, who is accused of killing three people last week.

item.title: What We Know About the Israeli Forces Fighting in Lebanon
item.description: The Israeli military has sent troops from four divisions across the border into Lebanon, but has not publicly disclosed how many.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli military vehicles staging near the border with Lebanon earlier this month.

item.title: U.K.’s MI5 Chief Says Russian Spies Seek to ‘Generate Mayhem’
item.description: The head of Britain’s domestic security service said Russia’s military intelligence service was pursuing “dangerous actions conducted with increasing recklessness.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ken McCallum, director general of MI5, speaking in west London on Tuesday.

item.title: Netanyahu Says Israel Killed Nasrallah’s Replacement and ‘the Replacement of the Replacement’
item.description: Hashem Safieddine had been expected to succeed Hassan Nasrallah, his cousin. It was not immediately clear who “the replacement of the replacement” was.
item.dc:creator: Johnatan Reiss
item.media:description: Hashem Safieddine, center, in a southern suburb of Beirut, in August.

item.title: France’s Government Survives a No-Confidence Vote
item.description: The outcome was not a surprise but signals a treacherous road ahead for the country’s divided legislature.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier of France in Paris on Monday. A no-confidence vote against his government failed on Tuesday.

item.title: Beer Can Art at a Dutch Museum Is Accidentally Thrown Out
item.description: Two beer cans were displayed in a Dutch museum. Then they were accidentally thrown out.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather

item.title: Does My Home Have Lead Pipes? And What Can I Do About Them?
item.description: New rules will require utilities to replace lead pipes nationwide. That will take time, but you can protect yourself by taking these steps.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times
item.media:description: A lead pipe in a Chicago home. It’s possible to identify lead pipes with a magnet and by lightly scratching the metal.

item.title: Iran Crisis Ignites New Debate About Trump’s Nuclear Deal Exit
item.description: President Donald J. Trump labeled it “the worst deal in history.” But critics of the withdrawal say it prompted Iran to accelerate its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: In May 2018, President Donald J. Trump announced that the United States would no longer abide by the Iran nuclear deal.

item.title: U.N. Official Took $3 Million in Secret Gifts From Businessman
item.description: The official secretly took $3 million in gifts from a businessman to whom he steered the organization’s funds, a court ruled. The U.N. got a song about the ocean.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: A U.N. court found last week that Vitaly Vanshelboim had committed fraud and “blatant misconduct” by failing to disclose gifts from a British businessman.

item.title: India’s Elections Offer Mixed Results for Modi
item.description: Two closely watched elections, in Haryana and the turbulent Jammu and Kashmir, kept the surprises coming after this summer’s shocking national outcome.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli, Hari Kumar and Showkat Nanda
item.media:description: Supporters of the opposition Congress Party celebrating on Tuesday in Srinagar, in Jammu and Kashmir. Congress and its allies won overwhelmingly in the territory.

item.title: Russia Pushes Forward in Ukraine’s East After Fall of Vuhledar
item.description: Russian troops have now entered Toretsk, a strategic hilltop city, and are pressing with assaults elsewhere in the Donetsk region.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen near Toretsk, in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, in September.

item.title: What Is Hamas Capable of After a Year of War?
item.description: The Palestinian militant group fired rockets at Israel on the anniversary of its Oct. 7 attacks.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene of a rocket assault in Kfar Chabad, Israel, on Monday.
